articles.headline: Frustrating Hurdle at Customs
articles.snippet: Some applications for Global Entry and other trusted traveler programs have been rejected for a minor brush with law enforcement or customs inspectors.
articles.abstract: Some applications for Global Entry and other trusted traveler programs have been rejected for a minor brush with law enforcement or customs inspectors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s trusted traveler program has proved itself more popular than officials expected, with 1.2 million people now eligible to speed up their entry to this country using a self-service kiosk rather than waiting to speak to a customs agent at the airport.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Lowers Its Forecast for Global Growth
articles.snippet: The fund foresees global growth of 3.3 percent in 2012 and 3.6 percent in 2013, down from the outlook it offered in July.
articles.abstract: The fund foresees global growth of 3.3 percent in 2012 and 3.6 percent in 2013, down from the outlook it offered in July.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund is cutting its global economic forecasts yet again, calling the risks of a slowdown “alarmingly high,” primarily because of policy uncertainty in the United States and Europe.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart and AmEx in Prepaid Card Deal
articles.snippet: A booming market creates a surprising alliance.
articles.abstract: A booming market creates a surprising alliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores is taking another leap into the banking world, announcing on Monday a prepaid card and debit account with American Express that will give low-income consumers access to features like smartphone deposits.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Investors’ Billion-Dollar Fraud Fighter
articles.snippet: With last month’s Bank of America settlement, Max Berger has been responsible for six securities class-action settlements of more than $1 billion.
articles.abstract: With last month’s Bank of America settlement, Max Berger has been responsible for six securities class-action settlements of more than $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days after securing the largest shareholder recovery arising from the financial crisis — $2.43 billion from Bank of America — the plaintiffs’ lawyer Max W. Berger was not taking a victory lap.

articles.headline: Ireland Plans Bold Measures to Lift Housing
articles.snippet: The initiative, which would lower a borrower’s monthly payment, could prevent a tide of foreclosures. If it works, the plan could provide a road map for other troubled countries.
articles.abstract: The initiative, which would lower a borrower’s monthly payment, could prevent a tide of foreclosures. If it works, the plan could provide a road map for other troubled countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — With its economy still reeling from the housing crash, Ireland is making a bold move to help tens of thousands of struggling homeowners.

articles.headline: South Africa Has a Black ‘Idol.’ The Surprise Is That It’s a First.
articles.snippet: In South Africa, nothing, not even a singing competition, escapes examination under a powerful racial lens.
articles.abstract: In South Africa, nothing, not even a singing competition, escapes examination under a powerful racial lens.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — When Khaya Mthethwa breathed out the last notes of Nicki Minaj’s “Super Bass,” a song he had heard for the first time that same day, the judges of “Idols SA,” the South African version of “American Idol,” were blown away.

articles.headline: Race and College Admissions, Facing a New Test by Justices
articles.snippet: This week, the Supreme Court is to hear the case of Abigail Fisher, who said she was rejected by a university because she is white, drawing new attention to affirmative action’s constitutionality.
articles.abstract: This week, the Supreme Court is to hear the case of Abigail Fisher, who said she was rejected by a university because she is white, drawing new attention to affirmative action’s constitutionality.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Abigail Fisher is a slight young woman with strawberry blond hair, a smile that needs little prompting, a determined manner and a good academic record. She played soccer in high school, and she is an accomplished cellist.

articles.headline: Welcoming Higher Taxes, but Not That High
articles.snippet: A proposed 75 percent tax in France is being protested by many of the nation’s wealthiest executives, including some who had called for higher taxes.
articles.abstract: A proposed 75 percent tax in France is being protested by many of the nation’s wealthiest executives, including some who had called for higher taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — A little over a year ago, some of the most prominent and wealthy executives in France signed a petition seeking higher taxes on themselves. Yes, higher taxes.

articles.headline: New ‘Super PACs’ Alter Landscape for House Races
articles.snippet: A possibly potent kind of super PAC is proliferating in the closing weeks of the campaign, transforming Congressional races with a barrage of outside money.
articles.abstract: A possibly potent kind of super PAC is proliferating in the closing weeks of the campaign, transforming Congressional races with a barrage of outside money.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the shadow of the supersize “super PACs” that have reshaped the battle for the White House and Senate, a new and potentially potent kind of super PAC is proliferating in the closing weeks of the campaign and taking aim at House races.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: With New Vigor, Romney Resets Ohio Campaign
articles.snippet: If one place is emerging as a test of Mitt Romney’s ability to capitalize on a new dynamic in the presidential race, it is Ohio, which every Republican president in the nation’s history has carried.
articles.abstract: If one place is emerging as a test of Mitt Romney’s ability to capitalize on a new dynamic in the presidential race, it is Ohio, which every Republican president in the nation’s history has carried.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — If one place is emerging as a test of Mitt Romney’s ability to capitalize on a new dynamic in the presidential race, it is Ohio, where he is intensifying his advertising, deploying more troops and spending four of the next five days.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Mexico Kills a Drug Kingpin, but the Body Gets Away
articles.snippet: The death of Heriberto Lazcano, known as El Lazca and the main leader of the Zetas, was confirmed through fingerprint analysis, the navy said. But in an odd twist, the corpse was quickly stolen.
articles.abstract: The death of Heriberto Lazcano, known as El Lazca and the main leader of the Zetas, was confirmed through fingerprint analysis, the navy said. But in an odd twist, the corpse was quickly stolen.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — It seemed such a triumphant moment in the drug war: the leader of the Zetas, one of the country’s biggest and most ruthless gangs, killed by the celebrated Mexican Marines in a fierce battle with guns and grenades.

articles.headline: In China Protests, Japanese Car Sales Suffer
articles.snippet: Japanese automakers have cut manufacturing by up to half in China after violent anti-Japanese protests over disputed islands in which Japanese-brand cars and even their owners were targeted.
articles.abstract: Japanese automakers have cut manufacturing by up to half in China after violent anti-Japanese protests over disputed islands in which Japanese-brand cars and even their owners were targeted.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Japanese automakers suffered plunging sales in China last month and have cut manufacturing by up to half in China this month after violent anti-Japanese protests against Japanese-brand cars and even their owners.
